item.title: Ecological Stoichiometry: Population Dynamics
item.author: grixor@gmail.com (Trang Le)
item.description: Lauren Yamane talked about Andersen et al. (2004) in our Ecological Stoichiometry course today. Here are her slides, and below, my rough notes on the paper: Notes on the Paper ------------------ - Stoichiometry is a way of representing food quality - there is evidence that consumers have preference for high quality (e.g., low C:N) food. - There is often a mismatch between composition of prey (autotrophs) and needs of consumers.

item.title: Dynamics of Coupled Nutrient Cycling and Acclimation: 3 Modeling Papers
item.author: grixor@gmail.com (Trang Le)
item.description:
Tomorrow in my stoichiometry seminar I'll be talking about the dynamics of growth under multiple nutrient limitation and acclimation. Here are my notes:
Rastetter and Shaver (1992) ---------------------------
In this paper, Rastetter and Shaver introduce a model of plant growth on multiple nutrients, with the goal of understanding the conditions under which single- and multiple-nutrient limitation arise, the difference between short- and long-term behavior, and the role of

item.title: Ecological Stoichiometry: The Perils of Famine and Plenty
item.author: grixor@gmail.com (Trang Le)
item.description: Pretty raw notes this week from a discussion about how food webs respond to nutrient starvation and excess. ### Whalen on consumption in Food Webs - Boersma and Elser (2006) - fitness cost of excessive P. Implications for models - but what about competition as a more likely limiting factor? - Not sure about the "food left on the table" argument. - What about the metabolic costs? Not mentioned in the paper.

item.title: Seminar in Ecological Stoichiometry: Day 1
item.author: grixor@gmail.com (Trang Le)
item.description: My advisor [Alan Hastings](http://two.ucdavis.edu/~me/) and colleague [Alison Marklein](http://www.researchgate.net/profile/Alison_Marklein/) have put together a great seminar this quarter on theoretical appraoches to nutrient flows and ecological stochiometry. I'm excited because this bridges my own current work, in population modeling, with my undergraduate training in ecosystem- and biogiochemical-based ecology. I'll try to blog about the papers we read as we go, and I've created a public [Mendeley Group](http://www.mendeley.com/groups/2632651/ecological-stoichiometry/papers/) where I'll be posting the readings.
